citeinfo.origin: National Atlas of the United States
citeinfo.title: United States National Atlas Water Feature Lines, 2022

descript.abstract: U.S. National Atlas Water Feature Lines - Rivers and Streams represents the linear water features (for example, aqueducts, canals, intracoastal waterways, and streams) of the United States.
descript.purpose: U.S. National Atlas Water Feature Lines - Rivers and Streams provides the linear water features for geographic display and analysis at regional and national levels.

cntinfo.cntinst:
In the United States- Direct all inquiries regarding software/data pricing and consulting services to your local Esri Regional Office. For support, contact Esri by telephone (voice) between 5:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. Pacific time, Monday through Friday, by dialing +1-888-377-4575; facsimile (fax) available at +1-909-792-0960; or visit https://support.esri.com/; Esri holidays excluded. Email and chat are available through the Support page on My Esri (https://my.esri.com).
Outside the United States- Direct all inquiries regarding software/data pricing, sales, support, and consulting services to your local Esri Office. This information can be found at https://www.esri.com/en-us/contact#c=us&t=0. For other questions or comments, you may contact Esri headquarters by email, telephone, or fax or write to us.

dataqual.logic: The dataset is converted to file geodatabase (FGDB) format using tools in ArcGIS. The geometry is checked, and if needed repaired.
dataqual.complete:
After processing, the dataset is checked for drawing display and number of records and file sizes compared with source materials.
This map layer contains streams of the United States and Puerto Rico. Only streams appropriate for a 1:1,000,000-scale data set are included. Preference was given to natural waterways, although a limited number of canals and aqueducts are included. Boundaries for the map layer are generally the 1:1,000,000-scale national boundaries and coastlines. The Intracoastal Waterway is the exception to this, in that it is outside the coastline.

horizpa.horizpar:
Streams are in approximately the same locations as in the Medium- Resolution National Hydrography Dataset NHDFlowline feature class used as a source. However, many processes and editing tasks resulted in the movement of streams from their original positions, including: extending or trimming streams to intersect the coastline or international boundaries; moving streams to follow county, state, and international boundaries where the boundary is coincident with the stream; moving streams 300 meters from transportation features if the two were parallel; increasing the gap between headwater streams in neighboring watersheds; adjusting streams to their proper route through water bodies; splitting streams at water body boundaries; snapping streams to streams in neighboring hydrologic subregions and regions; moving streams to ensure network connectivity; and moving streams to match imagery.
Horizontal positions are specified in geographic coordinates in decimal degrees. Latitudes are given to the nearest 0.000150. Longitudes are given to the nearest 0.000150. The positional accuracy is unknown.

citeinfo.origin: National Atlas of the United States
citeinfo.title: 1:1,000,000-Scale Streams of the United States

procstep.procdesc: The following steps were performed by Esri: Downloaded the compressed file from the National Atlas of the United States and extracted it. Removed unneeded fields. Renamed some fields. Combined all fields but MILES and then summarized and dissolved on it to reduce the number of features. Projected the dataset into WGS 1984. Converted the dataset into a file geodatabase.

enttyp.enttypd: The lines represent the linear water features within the United States.
enttyp.enttypds: National Atlas of the United States

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: The proper name of the water feature.
attr.attrdefs: National Atlas of the United States
National Atlas of the United States

edom.edomvds: National Atlas of the United States
edom.edomvd: A structure designed to transport domestic or industrial water from a supply source to a distribution point, often by gravity.

edom.edomvds: National Atlas of the United States
edom.edomvd: A connector that allows flow to be networked through water bodies.

edom.edomvds: National Atlas of the United States
edom.edomvd: An artificial open waterway constructed to transport water, to irrigate or drain land, to connect two or more bodies of water, or to serve as a waterway for water craft.

edom.edomvds: National Atlas of the United States
edom.edomvd: A system of rivers, canals, and designated channels along the Atlantic and Gulf Coasts of the United States.

edom.edomvds: National Atlas of the United States
National Atlas of the United States
edom.edomvd: A body of flowing water that contains water for only part of the year.

attr.attrdef: The two-letter abbreviation for each state where the water feature is located. If the water feature falls in two States, both codes are listed, separated by a dash.
attr.attrdefs: Department of Commerce, National Institute of Standards and Technology

codesetd.codesets: National Institute of Standards and Technology

attr.attrdef: The two-digit Hydrologic Unit Code for major river basins. Leading zeroes are not shown.
attr.attrdefs: National Atlas of the United States

attr.attrdef: The length of the water feature in miles, calculated using the North America Albers Equal Area Conic projection.
attr.attrdefs: National Atlas of the United States

attr.attrdef: Length of feature in internal units.

attrdomv.udom: Positive real numbers that are automatically generated.
